column1: In our system all values are produced at fixed intervals: 10 ms
column2: 100 ms and 1000 ms. I know the producing interval for each value
column3: so if a client requests the item at a faster interval than it is being produced

column1: If a value is produced at 10 ms rate
column2: but a client requests it at 1000 ms rate
column3: I will sample it at 1000 ms. According to Nyquist theorem
column4: the client would have to sample the value at half the interval the value is produced
column5: which is wasting CPU cycles on the server.

column1: We have a value produced at 10 ms rate. Two clients connect to the server
column2: one monitors the value at 10 ms and the other at 100 ms. Every 100 ms I would need to read the value from my data store twice
column3: to serve both clients. If it would be possible for me to manage the monitored items myself
column4: I would always sample the value once
column5: but every tenth time I would provide the sample also for the slower client.

column2: but in our system we have multiple connected clients with each one reading over 2000 nodes per second. When scaling up the CPU overhead starts to add up."
